titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Dean and Fanny Wickes Papers
titlestmt.author: Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Monday March 25, 2019 at 22:55

did.unittitle: Dean and Fanny Wickes Papers
did.abstract: Dean and Fanny Wickes were missionaries serving in Shandong from 1912 to 1934 under the North China Mission of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions. Correspondence, writings, photographs, and collected material document the life and work of these missionaries who were engaged in educational and evangelistic work.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Dean and Fanny Wickes Papers (RG 257), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library

chronitem.event: Dean Rockwell Wickes born in Granville, Ohio
Graduated from the University of Chicago, having received a Senior College Scholarship for excellence in the Department of Geology, and Phi Beta Kappa (1904)
Received Master's degree from Yale University
Received B.D. from Yale Divinity School
Received Ph.D. from the University of Chicago, with focus on New Testament and Religious Education
Married Fanny Rollinson Sweeny, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis LaBaume Sweeny

Dean and Fanny appointed missionaries of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions and sailed to China, where they were stationed first in Peking [Beijing] for language study and then at the ABCFM station in T'ungchou/T'unghsien [Tongxian] as of September, 1913, where Dean taught at North China Union College. Summers were spent at the missionary retreat area in Peitaiho [Beidaihe].
Daughter Alice born
Family based in Peking [Beijing], Dean teaching at Theological College
Family on furlough in U.S., Dean studying at Union Theological Seminary, New York
Return to China; family based in T'unghsien [Tongxian]
Death of infant daughter Mary Frances
Birth of daughter Margaret
Family moved to Lintsing [Linqing]
Birth of daughter Eleanor
Furlough in U.S.; Dean studying at Union Theological Seminary, New York, received S.T.M. degree
Return to China; based in Lintsing [Linqing]; Dean at Ellis Layman's Christian Training School
Family moves to Tehchow [Dezhou] as Lintsing station closes
Family informed that ABCFM can no longer support them in China; Dean returns to U.S. and finds job at Library of Congress
Fanny and Eleanor in in Los Angeles; move to Washington, D.C. in August; Dean is employed by Research Division of Soil Erosion, Department of Agriculture
Death of Fanny Wickes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Dean and Fanny Wickes papers provide valuable documentation of their work as missionaries of the North China Mission of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions during the years 1912 to 1934. The Wickes were well-educated individuals dedicated to their work in China. Their letters home to their parents are detailed and substantial, with a focus on recounting their daily activities and surroundings in China.The Wickes papers complement other collections held at the Yale Divinity Library, including fellow North China Mission missionaries Earle and Thelma Ballou, Constance Buell, Emery Ellis, Lewis and Lois Gilbert, James and Maude Hunter, Helen Kintner, Harold Matthews, Alice Reed, Olga Robinson, and Ernest Shaw.
The Family Correspondence of Series I is primarily from the Wickes to their parents, a regular series of detailed letters. General Correspondence includes letters to and from colleagues in China.
Series II provides fairly sparse biographical documentation but does include family photograph albums and statements by the Wickes regarding their faith and work.

The Mission-related Collected Material of Series III provides insight into issues and concerns of the American Board mission during this era of political disruption in China and financial stress for missions.

Series IV contains a number of interesting reflections by both Dean and Fanny Wickes on their work and on events and customs in China. Some of these writings were published and others prepared to inform their supporters in the U.S.

controlaccess.subject: Mission -- China
controlaccess.corpname: American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions

did.unittitle: Correspondence
Family correspondence
Dean and Fanny Wickes to/from their parents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters are primarily from Dean and Fanny to their parents. In later years there are some letters of their daughter Alice and from the parents.

FW's mother returns to U.S.; some students leave school to work in France and Britain during war; DW chairs committee to celebrate 50 years of Christian work in T'ungchou
College at T'ungchou to be moved to Peking as part of federated university; travel to Peitaiho for summer
Birth of daughter Alice on August 7
Re. life in T'ungchou; Alice's growth
T'ungchou changed to T'unghsien; evangelism trips
DW trip to Paoti to pay laborers and evangelize; planning joint missions at University of Peking; travel to Peitaiho for summer
DW returns to T'unghsien for Teachers' Institute; family moves to Peking; DW teaching at Theological College

Teaching in Peking; Provincial Association meetings; furlough plans
Return to U.S. for furlough; DW studying at Union Theological Seminary
DW studying at Union Theological Seminary
Return to China; stationed in T'unghsien with trips to countryside, including Chang Hsin Tien
DW in Tai Shui and elsewhere doing relief work; extreme poverty in area; daughter Mary Frances born
DW ill with measles; continues relief work; to Peitaiho for summer
Based in T'unghsien with evangelistic trips to out-stations; whooping cough at station
Daughter Mary Frances dies of cerebral meningitis; family to Peitaiho for summer; DW makes country trips; political and military unrest in area
DW on country preaching trip; 50th anniversary of Paotingfu station; teaching
Planning summer conference in WoFoSsu; to Peitaiho for summer
Return to T'unghsien; birth of daughter Margaret on October 20
DW visiting villages and market towns; sings with Peking Choral Society
Preaching trips to countryside
Association meetings; village visits
Family at Peitaiho; DW teaching summer school in Peking; flooding in area
Return to T'unghsien; DW doing relief work following floods; political unrest adds to difficulties; DW resumes country trips
T'unghsien city police and Governor of Metropolitan District start Christian meetings for staff; Association meeting includes discussion re. Wickes family moving to Lintsing station
DW resumes country trips; to Peitaiho for summer
Wickes family moves to Lintsing in October; DW takes country trip
Training School for Laymen established; DW teaching a three year course
Based in Lintsing; DW teaching at Bible school; military unrest in area
Opening of training school for practical service in the community; 40th anniversary of mission work in Lintsing
Council meetings in Tientsin [Tianjin]; DW's book "Flowers of Peitaiho" published; to Peitaiho for summer
DW to summer conference in Tehchow; to Ching Ping to organize a church; daughter Eleanor born October 13
Furlough plans; women and children ordered to leave Lintsing due to incident in Nanking; FW and girls go to Tientsin, then Korea
DW remains in China to finish up work; family sails to U.S. from Kobe, Japan in June; travel to NY, visiting FW's family
DW studying at Union Seminary; family in Poughkeepsie
DW graduates from Union Seminary; family travels to CA and leaves for China
Based in Lintsing; school resumes; DW visits village to examine candidates for church membership; electricity installed in home
DW to Peking for meetings; family to Peitaiho; new building for training school; trip to country station
Summer conference; problems with bandits; teaching, family life
DW at conference in Peking; life in Lintsing, includes letters from daughter Alice at North China American School to her grandparents
DW to country for visit; Fanny and children to Peitaiho in May; new grain seeds bring better harvest
DW returns to Lintsing for conference; illness prevents return to Peitaiho; FW has operation in Peking
Military unrest in area; Fanny and girls return to Lintsing; holiday celebrations
DW teaching; country trips; family life and illnesses

Incl. letters regarding the Tehchow incident when Dr. Tucker killed a robber at mission hospital

DW establishes village school in Wang Chia Li Chuang; plan for health work in country center; holiday celebrations
Lintsing and Tehchow stations to be merged; DW in Pi Hsueh Tien for extended session of classes
Approach of Japanese troops delays Council meeting; Alice's school closes early
DW to Peiping for North China Council meeting; Lintsing personnel to move to Tehchow; family to Peitaiho

FW living in Los Angeles with DW's father; DW appointed to Research Division of Soil Erosion, Department of Agriculture
FW and girls move to Washington DC in August; FW dies in November

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are primarily typescript and handwritten notes and essays by Dean and Fanny Wickes, in some cases reports to their supporters. Authorship of some writings is unclear.

did.unittitle: Including "The Winter Palace of Peking", "In Peking", "Getting Started in the Work" by FW
Including "The Cult of Blood" (published in Peking Gazette)by FW, "The College and the Academy" (re. North China Union College), "The Work of the TungChou Station"
Including ""The Touch of the West", Report of FW's visit to Third Moon Fair; "Report on Educational Work in Tungchou", "Language and its Study", "Notes on General Conditions"

Including ""Our Colleagues", "Soldiers and Christian Soldiers in China", "A Festive Evening in Tunghsien", "A Jingle of Chinese History", "Notes on Tungchou Temples", "The Everyday Life of a Common Chinese Woman"
Including newsletter from Goodrich Girls' School, Tunghsien, "Bound Feet and Free", "Peking Industries", sermons
Including "They Are Hungry for the Gospel of Jesus Christ", "Our Answer" (poem re. their withdrawal from mission), excerpts from letter to North China Council
